growth_loops_are_changing.name: Growth Loops Are Changing
growth_loops_are_changing.thesis: AI isn't just changing products. It's changing how products grow. The growth loops that built the last generation of companies are either accelerating, breaking, or being replaced by something new.
shifts: Visible output change is the new viral loop
AI that reduces friction compounds. AI that adds capability often doesn't.
Platform vs. layer: Products that embed into workflows grow differently from products that try to be the destination
growth_loops_are_changing.series_tag: Part of a series on how AI is changing the way products grow — the loops that work, the ones that don't, and what it tells us about how people adopt technology now.

structure.description: Personal observation + tension. Why this product matters to the 'growth loops are changing' argument
What the product does + personal experience. Ground in real usage, not theory
Name and dissect 3-4 growth loops. Show which are pre-AI, AI-native, or breaking
How loops feed each other — or don't. Reveal where growth engine has gaps
Connect to behavioral shift. What this tells us about AI and growth
Takeaways for builders. Specific, actionable, tied to shifts
Land the thesis. One clean observation about what's changing

measurement_gap.name: The Measurement Gap
measurement_gap.thesis: Growth loops are changing. Most teams are still measuring the old ones. Analytics teams are still measuring growth the way they did pre-AI. AI changed the loops. But the dashboards didn't update.
shifts: Teams measure AI adoption. They should measure behavior replacement.
The insight plateau is killing retention — and dashboards can't see it.
AI features improve products but don't grow them. Most teams can't tell the difference.
Teams measure time-in-app. The best AI products measure time-to-done.
Standard growth metrics miss AI-specific leading indicators.
measurement_gap.series_tag: Part of a series on measuring what matters in AI-era growth — the metrics that are broken, the ones that work, and the experiments that tell you the difference.

thinking_layer.name: The Thinking Layer
thinking_layer.thesis: AI can do the analysis. It can't do the thinking. Everyone has access to the same AI tools now. The difference isn't the tool. It's what you ask it to do. The thinking directed the AI, not the other way around. And that thinking is the part that doesn't get commoditized.
differentiators: Product analytics layer: Event taxonomy design, data model thinking, instrumentation specifics. Language of someone who's built analytics infrastructure (Segment, BigQuery, Amplitude, Looker).

AI-as-thinking-partner: Not just better prompts, but AI used inside the analytical workflow as a reasoning partner — pressure-testing hypotheses, modeling data before you have it, generating counter-hypotheses.
shifts: Decomposition: Aggregate metrics hide distinct behaviors with different retention trajectories. (Wispr: voice-to-typed ratio event schema)
Inversion: Ask 'under what conditions would this stop working?' instead of 'why is this working?' (Oura: insight_depth event property)
Second-order thinking: Ask 'what does this make possible, and what does that change?' (Todoist: capture window time-series)
Reframe unit of analysis: Same data, different question, different insight. (Notion: content_origin event taxonomy)
thinking_layer.series_tag: Part of a series on thinking with AI — applied to real products, showing how better questions produce better analysis than better tools ever could.
structure_elements: Real user quotes as raw material (2-3 contrasting quotes showing behavioral divergence)
The obvious question (standard analyst frame + generic AI prompt)
The reframe (thinking skill applied, named lightly)
AI prompt comparison (generic vs. reframed, showing AI as reasoning partner)
What this surfaces (strategic implications + specific instrumentation details)
Where else this applies (2-3 transferable examples)
Why this matters (moat message lands implicitly)

product_analytics_examples.Wispr: voice-to-typed ratio derivable from input_method event property, computed at user-session level
product_analytics_examples.Oura: insight_depth property (glance | explore | deep_dive) on score_viewed event
product_analytics_examples.Todoist: capture windows from task_created timestamps, no new instrumentation needed
product_analytics_examples.Notion: Full event schema: content_origin_type, paste_with_formatting_detection, ai_interaction_depth, time_to_first_content

posting_order.strategy: Interleave by app, not by pillar
posting_order.reasoning: Each app gets a three-post arc. Reader who follows one app gets full depth. Reader who catches one post from each pillar gets breadth.

multi_pillar_arcs.description: Same product analyzed through all 3 pillars

Wispr: Pillar 3: Decomposition — 4.7 stars hiding 3 products → voice-to-typed ratio event schema
Oura: Pillar 3: Inversion — success causing churn → insight_depth event property
Todoist: Pillar 3: Second-order — 5x is the start, not the answer → capture window time-series
Notion: Pillar 3: Unit of analysis — adoption ≠ cognitive workflow → content_origin event taxonomy
